urn:contentItem:6GDY-9DJ3-S07C-S478-00000-00Air quality alert to linger through today2025-08-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:56:33ZLexisNexisREGIONPg. B1Air quality alert to linger through todayNick Vadala (Staff Writer)

Smoke from numerous Canadian wildfires is again impacting the Philadelphia region this week, with environmental authorities issuing code orange air quality alerts largely in effect through Tuesday as a result of the blazes' aftermath settling in on the area.

The wildfires' smoke will likely stick around the Philadelphia region through Tuesday, driving up fine particulate pollution levels in the late morning and afternoon, the Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection said. Much of central and eastern Pennsylvania was expected to experience similar air-quality issues, the department added.

As a result, the department issued a code orange alert through midnight Tuesday for those areas of the state, including Philadelphia and its collar counties. The alert followed a previous code orange alert - technically known as a Code Orange Air Quality Action Day - issued Monday for ozone pollution on the region.

The New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection, too, put a number of its counties under a code orange air quality alert Monday due to the wildfire smoke's impact in the Garden State. Many areas in South Jersey - including Camden, Cherry Hill, Mount Holly, and Glassboro - were expected to remain under the alert until midnight Monday.

And all of Delaware was likewise under a code orange alert Monday, the state's Department of Natural Resources and Environmental Control said. Tuesday in the First State is likely to see some wildfire smoke impacts, but ozone levels were expected to be limited by increased cloud cover, leading to a moderate air quality index, one step below a code orange, the department indicated.

Ozone levels in the Philadelphia area were expected to reach peak levels Monday afternoon, the Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection said in a statement. While high levels of ozone are common in summer, they can increase due to environmental factors like wildfire smoke, which reacts with sunlight to create additional ozone molecules, the department added.

Airborne fine particulates, referred to as PM2.5 due to their size in micrometers, can easily be inhaled and lead to health issues, according to the Environmental Protection Agency. They also contribute to the hazy effect that can be present during air quality alerts.

The level of pollution seen on code orange days can be challenging to people respiratory problems, as well as young children and the elderly. Those groups should limit their time outdoors to reduce their exposure to pollutants, and participate in "less strenuous activities" if they must be outside, according to the agency's AirNow website.

The code orange alerts come amid more than 700 active fires in Canada, roughly 200 of which are considered to be burning out of control as of Monday evening, according to the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre. Smoke from the fires has prompted air quality alerts in a number of states near the Canadian border in recent days, and put cities like Detroit and Minneapolis among those with the worst air quality in the world Monday, rankings from IQAir indicate.

The Philadelphia region last week saw similar air quality issues as a result of the wildfires. Those came during a period of hot, humid weather that broke Friday, resulting in pleasant temperatures following a bout of storms.

Like Monday, Tuesday is expected to be sunny and approaching 90 degrees, with low humidity, according to the National Weather Service. Highs in the mid-80s are expected to remain throughout the week.

urn:contentItem:6DWX-VGC3-S2R8-43HP-00000-00Researchers at Nanjing University Publish New Study Findings on Climate Change (An AutoML-Powered Analysis Framework for Forest Fire Forecasting: Adapting to Climate Change Dynamics)2025-01-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:56:33ZLexisNexisCLIMATE CHANGEResearchers at Nanjing University Publish New Study Findings on Climate Change (An AutoML-Powered Analysis Framework for Forest Fire Forecasting: Adapting to Climate Change Dynamics)


2025 JAN 15 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Climate Change Daily News -- Fresh data on climate change are presented in a new report. According to news reporting originating from Nanjing, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Wildfires pose a serious threat to ecosystems and human safety, and with the backdrop of global climate change, the prediction of forest fires has become increasingly important."


Our news reporters obtained a quote from the research from Nanjing University: "Traditional machine learning methods face challenges in forest fire prediction, such as difficulty identifying feature parameters, manual intervention in model selection, and hyperparameter tuning, which affect prediction accuracy and efficiency. This study proposes an analytical framework for forest fire prediction based on Automated Machine Learning (AutoML) technology to address the challenges traditional machine learning methods face in forest fire prediction. We collected meteorological, topographical, and vegetation data from Guangxi Province, with meteorological data covering 1994 to 2023, providing comprehensive background information for our prediction model. Using the prediction model, which was constructed with the AutoGluon framework, the experimental results indicate that models under the AutoGluon framework (e.g., KNeighborsDist classifier) significantly outperform traditional machine learning models in terms of accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-Score, with the highest accuracy rate reaching 0.960. Model error analysis shows that models under the AutoGluon framework perform better in error control."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "This study provides an efficient and accurate method for forest fire prediction, which is of great significance for decision-making in forest fire management and for protecting forest resources and ecological security."
For more information on this research see: An AutoML-Powered Analysis Framework for Forest Fire Forecasting: Adapting to Climate Change Dynamics. Atmosphere, 2024,15(12):1481. (Atmosphere - http://www.mdpi.com/journal/atmosphere/). The publisher for Atmosphere is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/atmos15121481.
Our news journalists report that more information may be obtained by contacting Shuo Zhang, School of Information Management, Nanjing University, Nanjing 210023, People's Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include Mengya Pan.
Keywords for this news article include: Nanjing University, Nanjing, People's Republic of China, Asia, Climate Change, Cyborgs, Emerging Technologies, Global Warming, Machine Learning.

urn:contentItem:6GKF-M0M3-RRRY-W4CC-00000-00Latest fire situation in Spain, live | Fire situation improves due to higher humidity in the environment2025-08-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:56:33ZLexisNexisLatest fire situation in Spain, live | Fire situation improves due to higher humidity in the environment


EL PAÍS offers free of charge the latest news about the fires. If you want to support our journalism, subscribe.
The situation of the forest fires has improved in the last hours due to the favorable evolution of the weather. Castilla y León is still pending the extinguishing works of the eight serious forest fires that affect mainly the provinces of León and Zamora. There have been relocations due to the improvement of the situation, but the evolution of the Anllares fire, which is advancing rapidly and has forced the evacuation of the village of Argayo del Sil (León), is being followed with concern. The large fires in Galicia are subsiding, but the fire-fighting services are not lowering their guard against the appearance of new fires such as those which have been declared in Pontevedra or Lugo. Asturias is still awaiting the evolution of the fires declared in the southwest of Asturias, especially in Degaña, where the firefighting operation is turning its attention. In Cáceres, after 10 days, the Jarilla fire has finally been stabilized, according to the Minister of Interior and Presidency of the Junta de Extremadura, Abel Bautista, after burning 17,300 hectares.


Go to topNew publicationsEl País
FOREST FIRES
An 'island' in the middle of the fires: the village that nobody evacuated on the border between Galicia and Castilla y León
Virginia Martínez
The village of Pradorramisquedo, with 16 inhabitants, is located in the southeast of the province of Ourense, about five kilometers from the border between Galicia and Castilla y León. The road that leads to the locality -which considerably increases the number of residents in summer- is the Zamorano ZA-102. On Thursday 14, most of the villages in the area, which belong to Zamora and surround Pradorramisquedo, were preventively evacuated by order of the Junta de Castilla y León due to one of the fires that have swept through Spain. But they, no. They were not afraid, but they do denounce lack of information on the part of the Galician Xunta. "We were outraged," says Óscar Javier Tamerón, 47. "If the problem was the smoke, they should have evicted Pradorramisquedo as well," adds this formwork worker while having a beer with other family members and neighbors in front of his house, this Friday.

FOREST FIRES
358,000 hectares in 15 days: how Spain burned in its blackest weeks
Luis Sevillano PiresMontse Hidalgo PerezJosé A. Álvarez
In just two weeks, Spain has suffered 19 of the 50 largest fires recorded in the last decade, according to the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS). The 358,000 hectares razed since August 8 have made 2025 the worst year in the country, with a total area already exceeding 400,000 hectares. Far behind is the record of 2022, when 306,000 hectares burned with fires as devastating as those of Losacio and Ferreras de Arriba, which devastated more than 60,000 hectares in the Sierra de la Culebra.
You can read the complete information here
Published at: 09:33 CEST 23/08/2025 El País
Good morning. In general, the situation of the forest fires has improved in the last hours and continues the relocation of neighbors of villages affected by the fires of Porto (Zamora) and Jarilla (Cáceres), where it has also de-escalated the danger, as in Molezuelas (Zamora). It is expected that the favorable evolution of the weather will help to extinguish and control the fires, since the maximum temperatures will decrease in the north, with associated fog at the beginning of the day and clouds of evolution that will help to humidify the environment.
Published at: 09:19 CEST 23/08/2025 and modified at 09:21 CEST 23/08/2025

urn:contentItem:6G7N-64D3-RS0T-04K1-00000-00Canadian wildfire smoke poised to again impact North Dakota2025-07-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:56:33ZLexisNexisAPg. 003Canadian wildfire smoke poised to again impact North DakotaBLAKE NICHOLSON Bismarck Tribune

Smoke from Canadian wildfires is expected to drift into North Dakota again in coming days, potentially degrading air quality.

Predictions from the BlueSky Canada forecasting system show smoke blanketing the state Thursday, with conditions worsening Thursday night and Friday.

North Dakota's Department of Environmental Quality cautioned residents about the expected conditions. People -- especially those with respiratory conditions -- are encouraged to limit outdoors activities when air quality is poor.

Hazy skies have been an on-and-off issue in the state all summer, at times reducing air quality to the "very unhealthy" and even "hazardous" categories. Wildfire smoke contains tiny pollutants that can move deep into lung tissue and enter the bloodstream, and has been linked to health complications including asthma, heart disease and other respiratory illnesses.

There have been about 3,000 total fires north of the border so far this year burning nearly 12 million acres, according to the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre. As a comparison, North Dakota encompasses about 44 million acres.

There were 514 active wildfires in Canada on Thursday -- more than double what there were a month ago -- and 141 of them were classified as out of control. Many of the out-of-control fires were in the provinces of Saskatchewan and Manitoba, which border North Dakota.

Air quality in northwestern North Dakota on Thursday afternoon was in the "moderate" category, while just across the Saskatchewan border it was rated "unhealthy."

Information on wildfires and air quality is on the DEQ website, at bit.ly/3OhrD7E. The federal Environmental Protection Agency’s map of fire and smoke conditions is at https://fire.airnow.gov/. The AirNow mobile phone app, and many other weather apps, also include air quality information. AirNow is a partnership of federal and state agencies including the Environmental Protection Agency and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

urn:contentItem:6GSB-BJR3-RVPF-F281-00000-00Deforestation Threatens Chiang Rai's Green Economy2025-09-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:56:33ZLexisNexisDeforestation Threatens Chiang Rai's Green EconomyJeff Tomas

CHIANG RAI - Northern Thailand is entering an era where green development is no longer just an idea. A small decrease in Thailand's forest area, only 0.03%, is now having an effect on supply chains across the north and is a sign for the whole country to take notice.

On a misty morning in Doi Tung, visitors still take in the sights, but now there is a new topic of conversation: the latest figures on Thailand's forest area for 2024. The country now holds forest cover at 31.46% of its land, about 101.78 million rai, down by roughly 32,884 rai or 0.03% from the year before.

While this sounds minor, for places like Chiang Rai, where the economy depends on natural resources, even small losses matter.

Local incomes from tourism, highland agriculture, food production, and water quality from upstream forests are all linked to healthy forests. This minor decline is now putting the entire northern economy to the test.

Forest Data Over a Decade: Loss Outpaces Gains

Over the last ten years (2015-2024), Thailand gained around 332,000 rai in new forests but lost over 832,000 rai in the same period. These numbers highlight a chronic issue: forest recovery efforts cannot keep up with land conversion and recurring risks.

- Natural regeneration in some areas
- Tree planting for economic or conservation benefits
- Land is being used for other activities
- Ongoing wildfires, which remain a recurring danger
- Development projects that use forest land still impact natural resources
Economic Impact and the Place of Forests in Chiang Rai's Economy

Chiang Rai's economy is built on tourism and high-value agriculture. Water sources originate from forests and sustain tea, coffee, cool-climate fruit, and organic farming, especially in the valleys. Eco-tourism, local homestays, community crafts, and farm-to-table businesses all start with forest health.

When even a small area of forest disappears, the hidden costs pile up: there is a higher risk of floods and droughts, poorer air during the dry season, and rising costs for health and tourism businesses. All these eat into profits, even if people do not notice it day to day.

While national figures only show a small decrease, the north - especially hill areas - faces the annual risk of wildfires and smoke. Tourism businesses, especially during the dry and hot season, suffer when air quality worsens. Everything from trip cancellations to higher insurance costs for visitors now depends on the number of clear-air days, which are linked directly to controlling fires and managing forest fuel loads.

Forests that remain or grow now drive new opportunities. Sustainable tourism, high-value agriculture like tea and coffee, and payment schemes for ecosystem services attract both visitors and investors. The local carbon credit market is also getting interest. For Chiang Rai, where branding focuses on clean air, natural beauty, and strong culture, keeping forests healthy is not just about the environment but a focused strategy for boosting income.

Several provinces in the north and central regions have increased their forest area by planning carefully and encouraging communities to get involved in forest management. This approach helps them create green products, GI goods, and develop low-carbon tourism.

Chiang Rai, at the crossroads of major tourism routes (such as Doi Tung, Mae Sai, Mae Fah Luang, and Mae Chan), needs to turn its natural strengths into real economic advantages by preserving its forests.

Chiang Rai's Pivotal Role in the North

Chiang Rai is not among the provinces with increased forest in the latest year, but it sits at the centre of a region that loses forest area the fastest. The north has around 63.19% forest cover (about 37.95 million rai), but lost close to 29,884 rai in 2024 alone. These figures are a warning for Chiang Rai, highlighting that the area is at risk of falling behind.

- Water sources such as the Kok, Ing, and upper Mekong rivers rely on forested areas in districts like Mae Fah Luang, Mae Sai, and along the border. Less buffer forest means less stable water for farming, tourism, and food industries.
- Air quality is central to visitors' confidence in Chiang Rai. Cities that can control wildfires and smoke will attract families, athletes, and trekkers who are willing to spend more.
- Green finance is becoming available for local tree planting, forest fire management, carbon credit projects, and low-carbon tourism. Chiang Rai's strong communities are in a good position to act as pilot schemes for green investment.
- Develop clear land use plans at sub-district and small watershed levels, setting up community-forest buffer zones and assigning fuel management quotas for each season.
- Support high-value agroforestry (like tea, coffee, macadamia, and cool-climate fruit) alongside environmental standards to secure premium prices.
- Build low-carbon travel routes, such as city walks, bike paths, and light trekking that connect museums, art hubs, and ethnic communities, aiming to boost per-visitor spending with experience-based packages.
- Improve real-time wildfire and fuel load data systems for tourism and agricultural operators to adjust activities and reduce cancellations.
The Bigger Picture for Northern Thailand in 2024

The northern region holds the highest proportion of forests in Thailand, but also suffers the greatest overall annual losses. Other regions show different trends:

- The West has 58.82% of its land as forest, with a loss of over 12,400 rai
- The south stands at 24.33% forest with a decrease of 5,225 rai
- The northeast has 14.89% forest, down by 732 rai
- The east managed to gain 4,374 rai, now covering 21.84% the land
- The central region gained the most, with 11,032 rai added to reach 21.57% forest cover

Central and eastern provinces have made gains by focusing on careful planning and economic benefits for communities. The north can adapt these strategies, but will also need fresh ideas for managing fuel loads, handling wildfires, and creating new incomes during the dry season to stop the cycle of forest loss.

Across the Country: Lessons in Forest Recovery

Many provinces, including Phayao, Nan, Phrae, Phitsanulok, Phetchabun, Uthai Thani, Chainat, Lopburi, Saraburi, Suphan Buri, Ang Thong, Nakhon Pathom, Prachinburi, Chachoengsao, Sa Kaeo, Chon Buri, Rayong, Chumphon, Satun, Nong Khai, Bueng Kan, Chaiyaphum, Khon Kaen, Kalasin, Roi Et, Nakhon Ratchasima, Buri Ram, and Surin, show that expanding forest area is possible with the right focus and tools.

Yet, there are still two provinces with no forest at all: Nonthaburi and Pathum Thani. These are urban centres facing the challenge of balancing city growth with green space. Meeting this challenge will help them reduce heat and improve air quality, supporting investment and quality of life.

A drop of just 0.03% in a single year may not seem serious, but the overall decade-long trend shows a consistent loss. Thailand needs to shift its approach. Chiang Rai now faces a key question: how to turn its natural setting into a source of ongoing, competitive advantage.

Immediate Action: Four Strategic Moves
- Plan the economy based on water catchment areas, aligning farming, tourism, and services with the capacity of upstream forests rather than just administrative boundaries.s
- Create deals for ecosystem services between urban centres and upland communities, letting city operators pay for forest care in exchange for clean water, air, and a stronger green image.
- Raise standards for low-carbon tourism across hotels, tours, and cafes, linking products to both environmental targets and local cultural identity.
- Develop agroforestry into a regional industry, connecting tea, coffee, and fruit supply chains to processors and cooler logistics, boosting value and lowering pressure on forests.
- Use open data and dedicated dashboards to give local businesses early warnings about fire risk, helping them plan events and keep guests informed.d
Forests as Economic Assets: The Chiang Rai Model

When forests are seen as assets, the economic cycle in Chiang Rai and the north becomes much stronger. Healthy forests lead to cleaner water and air, support valuable farming and tourism, and feed money back to local communities. This, in turn, brings back more forest cover.

Key Forest Facts for Thailand in 2024
- National forest area: 31.46%, or about 101,785,272 rai
- Change since last year: a decrease of 0.03% (32,884 rai)
- Over the past 10 years,s: 332,000 rai gained and 832,000 rai lost
- Northern region: 63.19% forest, losing 29,884 rai (largest decrease)
- Central region: 21.57% forest, gaining 11,032 rai (largest increase)
- Forestless provinces: Nonthaburi, Pathum Thani

Losing just 0.03 of % forest might seem unimportant in daily headlines. For Chiang Rai, which relies on green growth, it raises real concerns about future income and liveability. Now, the region must treat its forests as economic assets needing professional management.

If this happens, Chiang Rai will not only be better prepared for the annual haze but could stand out as a green city for the north, where nature is a direct source of jobs, money, and pride for its people.

urn:contentItem:6GKM-BNV3-RS0P-X55K-00000-00The Government will declare today "areas affected by emergency" after the fires, with the announcement of the first aids.2025-08-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:56:33ZLexisNexisThe Government will declare today "areas affected by emergency" after the fires, with the announcement of the first aids.


The Government will approve in the Council of Ministers this Tuesday the declaration of "areas affected by civil protection emergency" to the territories that are suffering from forest fires, as well as giving the green light to the creation of an inter-ministerial commission on climate change, which will meet already this morning at 09.00 hours under the leadership of the President of the Government, Pedro Sánchez.


Both measures were announced by the head of the Executive during his appearances on the occasion of last week's visits to Extremadura and Asturias, two of the territories affected by the fires that in 2025 have burned almost 400,000 hectares in Spanish territory, according to the European Commission's Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS) of Copernicus.
The Minister of Territorial Policy and Democratic Memory, Ángel Víctor Torrres, confirmed that after the meeting of the Council of Ministers, both the Vice-President for Ecological Transition, Sara Aagesen, and the Minister of the Interior, Fernando Grande-Marlaska, will announce the first aids to respond to the needs of those affected. "To all those who need it", he advanced in an interview in the 'Cadena Ser'.
At the last hour of this Monday, of the thirteen active fires in operational situation 2 communicated to the National Center of Alerts and Emergencies, seven belong to the community of Castilla y León (5 to León, one to Zamora and one to Salamanca), three to Asturias and three to Galicia (2 to Orense and one to Lugo), while there are three fires already stabilized and seven controlled fires.
The provisions of the Government will come after the leader of the opposition, Alberto Núñez Feijóo, announced Monday a comprehensive plan with 50 measures against forest fires that would include a national register of arsonists and that they are geolocated, professionalize Civil Protection, more aid and no taxes, and more support for livestock and the rural world.
Minister Torres already questioned Feijóo's plan on Monday because, as he recalled, the competences in fires "are perfectly clear", although he acknowledged that there are measures with "positive aspects" but believes that the proposals "are born wrong from the root". In addition, he accused the 'popular' of exercising a "permanent siege and a constant attack" on the Government of Pedro Sánchez, even when "they preside over most of the autonomous communities". "It is the world upside down," he lamented.
THE GOVERNMENT'S MEASURES AGAINST THE FIRES
The official declaration of "areas affected by a civil protection emergency", announced by Sánchez after his visit in Jarilla (Cáceres) and which will be approved this Tuesday, will imply the "commitment" of the Government to also face the task of reconstruction, once "they are extinguished and the economic impact on each and every one of the pockets of the neighbors of the affected municipalities is known".
The other measure that will be launched is the creation of a new inter-ministerial commission on climate change to pave the way for the achievement of a State pact against the climate emergency, which the President himself will head this Tuesday, just before the Council, and in which twenty-one government ministers will participate.
In detail, the commission announced by Sánchez after the visit to the town of Degaña (Asturias) will be headed by the third vice-president and head of Ecological Transition, Sara Aagesen, together with the Minister of the Interior, Fernando Grande Marlaska, as head of Civil Protection.
In this sense, in his appearance in Asturias, Sanchez again demanded the need to "resize" and "redefine all aspects related to mitigation and adaptation to climate change" in light of what happened this summer with the fires that have ravaged much of Spain and the record temperatures recorded in regions such as Asturias.
THE 50 MEASURES PROPOSED BY FEIJÓO
For his part, the president of the Popular Party (PP), Alberto Núñez Feijóo, announced on Monday a comprehensive plan with 50 measures against forest fires that, as he explained, will be sent immediately to the Cortes Generales. Among them, a national register of arsonists and that they are geolocated, professionalize Civil Protection, more aid and no taxes, and more support for livestock and the rural world.
"We have worked on a comprehensive response with 50 measures for the affected areas that include immediate aid to people, the repair of villages, the recovery of forest heritage and jobs, and preparation for future events," he said at a press conference at the party's headquarters.
Feijóo stressed that the proposals respond to three objectives: prompt attention to those affected, recovery of environments and jobs destroyed, and guarantees so that "a tragedy of these dimensions does not happen again".
The PP leader also defended the need to "objectify" emergency management to avoid political confrontation and proposed establishing "objective, transparent and binding" criteria under the leadership of experienced professionals. The aim, he said, is to guarantee the speed and coordination of regional resources, the Military Emergency Unit (UME), the logistical capabilities of the Army and the activation of European resources when necessary.

urn:contentItem:6GKM-BPK3-RS5Y-N32N-00000-0015 days of inferno: from state pre-emergency to 411,000 hectares burned2025-08-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:56:33ZLexisNexis15 days of inferno: from state pre-emergency to 411,000 hectares burned


Since the Ministry of the Interior declared 15 days ago the pre-emergency phase, in operational situation 1, of the General State Emergency Plan (Plegem) in the face of active forest fires in several communities, with some 138,000 hectares affected then, the forest disaster has almost tripled.


And is that of the 411,315 hectares that have burned in 2025, more than 270,000 correspond to this catastrophic fortnight in Spain, the worst wave of fires in thirty years.
A wave that has forced the evacuation of more than 33,000 people (some 700 are still evacuated from their homes).
In addition, since June, law enforcement agencies have arrested a total of 45 people for forest fires since the beginning of June, four of them during this weekend, and are investigating 133 people.
August 12 marked a turning point in the fires of the summer with the declaration of the pre-emergency phase, which does not involve the intervention of state agencies in the direction and management of emergencies of regional interest and, therefore, does not affect the powers of direction and management that correspond to the autonomous regions.
Also on the same day, the first meeting of the State Coordination and Management Committee (Cecod) was called to evaluate the situation and coordinate actions, which has met daily since then.
According to the latest update of the European Forest Fire Information System (EFFIS), a tool under the European Union (EU) Copernicus Earth observation and monitoring program, 411,315 hectares have burned in 2025 in at least 252 forest fires.
The figures of the Spanish Ministry for Ecological Transition only go up to August 17 (91,579.51 hectares and 55 fires of more than 500 hectares), but the voracity of the flames of the fires in force since that date or registered since then have pulverized those data.
Since August 11 alone, numerous mega-fires of more than 10,000 hectares have been recorded, and what is already considered the largest fire in the history of Spain since 1968, when official statistics began to be compiled, has been declared. It is the fire in the Zamora town of Molezuelas de la Carballeda, which affects the provinces of Zamora and León, in the center-north of the country, in which two men who were voluntarily helping to fight the flames died, and which affects 37,000 hectares.
On the other hand, the wave of fires that began on August 8 in Galicia has already devastated more than 90,000 hectares in that community, according to data from Medio Rural, which only reports fires of more than 20 hectares or affecting protected areas.
The most violent is that of Larouco, with around 30,000 hectares affected. It is the largest in the history of Galicia.
Among the largest fires - estimated at 500 hectares of forest area devastated, which may change when they are considered to be extinguished - in 2025 are the following:
- Molezuelas de la Carballeda (Zamora), with 37,000 hectares affected. The fire spread to the province of León. This could become the worst in Spain since 1968. The fire claimed the lives of two volunteers. - Larouco-Seadur (Ourense). Already considered the largest of all fires declared in Galicia since records have been kept, it has burned 30,000 hectares of the Galician part of Pena Trevinca, a natural area which is home to the oldest forest in Galicia. It has also reached the province of Lugo after jumping the river Sil.
- Chandrexa de Queixa (Ourense). More than 19,000 hectares (ha), already stabilized. - Oímbra and Xinzo de Limia (Ourense). Already 17,000 hectares (ha) devastated. - Jarilla (Cáceres), with 17,000 hectares, already stabilized.
- A Mezquita-A Esculqueira (Ourense), with 10,000 hectares. - Porto (Zamora). It already affects more than 10,000, according to the Copernicus system, and is the most worrying now in Zamora, as it impacts the Natural Park of Sanabria Lake, Segundera and Porto mountain ranges, but also the valley of Casaio in Ourense and the surroundings of the lake of Baña in León.
- Almanza (León), with 5,900 ha - Puercas, in Gallegos del Río (Zamora), with 4,700 ha - Carballeda de Valdeorras-Casaio, with 4,400 ha - Carballeda de Avia and Beade (Ourense), with 4,000 ha - Yeres, in Las Médulas (León), with 3.731 ha - Llamas de Cabrera (León), with 3,550 ha - Maceda (Ourense), 3,500 ha - Navalmoralejo (Toledo-Cáceres), with 3,256 ha - Méntrida (Toledo), with 3,189 ha - Paüls (Tarragona), with 2.879 ha - Caminomorisco (Cáceres), with 2,660 ha - A Granxa-Oímbra (Ourense) with 2,500 ha - Valdecaballeros (Badajoz), with 2,393 ha - Cuevas del Valle (Ávila), with 2,215 ha - Carballeda de Valdeorras-Casaio, with 2.000 ha - Santiso, Maceda (Ourense), with 1,700 ha - Navaluenga (Ávila), with 1,577 ha - Burguillos (Sevilla), with 1,350 ha - Benahadux (Almería), with 1,333 ha - Alcollarín (Cáceres), with 1,310 ha - Aldea del Cano (Cáceres), with 1,229 ha - Tres Cantos (Madrid), with 1,000 ha - Cuevas del Valle (Ávila), with 2,393 ha - Cuevas del Valle (Cáceres), with 2,215 ha - Carballeda del Valdeorras-Casaio, with 2,000 ha
- Tres Cantos (Madrid), with more than 2,000 ha - Cáceres, with 1.057 ha - Vilardevós-Vilar de Cervos, with 900 ha - Talarrubias (Badajoz), 838 ha - San Bartolomé de Pinares-Las Navas del Marqués (Ávila), 801 ha - Oliva de Mérida (Badajoz), 800 ha - Resoba (Palencia), 800 ha - Arroyomolinos (Cáceres), with 782 ha - Trujillo (Cáceres) 827 ha - Terroso, Vilardevós (Ourense), with 549 ha - Selaya (Cantabria) with 605 ha - Torrefeta (Lleida), with 5.282 ha.

urn:contentItem:6GNB-KKH3-RS2B-M1HR-00000-00Climate change fuelled wildfires of 'unprecedented intensity' in Spain and Portugal, experts say2025-09-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:56:33ZLexisNexisClimate change fuelled wildfires of 'unprecedented intensity' in Spain and Portugal, experts say

Researchers warn that simultaneous fires across Europe are overwhelming firefighting resources.

Climate change made weather that fuelled Portugal and Spain’s deadly wildfires this summer around 40 times more likely, new research has found.

Blazes in the Iberian Peninsula broke out at the end of July. Fuelled by temperatures above 40°C and strong winds, the flames spread extremely rapidly. The area burned by these wildfires has now broken records across Spain and Portugal.

A new super rapid scientific analysis by World Weather Attribution (WWA) has found that these hot, dry and windy conditions were made more likely and more intense by human-caused climate change.

Dr Clair Barnes, researcher for the Centre for Environmental Policy at Imperial College London, warns that the “astonishing” size of these fires is a “sign of what is to come” with hotter, drier, more flammable conditions becoming more severe with climate change.

It is giving rise to fires of “unprecedented intensity".

“With every fraction of a degree of warming, extreme, long-lasting heatwaves will continue to intensify, increasing the chance of huge wildfires like the ones that burned vast areas of the Iberian Peninsula,” she says.

Climate change made fire-prone conditions more intense

Scientists found climate change intensified the weather that enabled the explosive spread of the fires, including Spain’s hottest consecutive ten days on record.

The hot, dry and windy conditions that fuelled the fires in Spain and Portugal are now around 40 times more frequent and around 30 per cent more intense than they would be in a world without climate change.

Related

Climate change intensified weather that fuelled deadly wildfires in Türkiye, Greece and Cyprus

How flash droughts driven by climate change sparked record wildfires in Spain

Before climate change, similar extreme spells of hot, dry and windy conditions would have been incredibly rare and expected once every 500 years. Today, with 1.3°C of warming, they are expected once every 15 years.

Scientists also looked at the heatwave, finding that in a world without climate change, similar events would be expected less than every 2,500 years. With current warming, they are expected once every 13 years.

The results of the analysis back up a similar study recently released by WWA which found that climate change also intensified weather that fuelled deadly wildfires in Türkiye, Greece and Cyprus.

Europe’s firefighters are under pressure

Experts say the study also highlights the strain on firefighters in Europe. Weather conditions have sparked large, unpredictable wildfires across the south of the continent, stretching the EU's resources.

“Firefighters are increasingly working in chaotic and unpredictable conditions, tackling fires that behave in ways they’ve never seen before,” says Centre for Environmental Policy researcher, Theodore Keeping.

Firefighters are increasingly working in chaotic and unpredictable conditions, tackling fires that behave in ways they’ve never seen before, Theodore Keeping Centre for Environmental Policy researcher

As fires raged on 13 August, Spain made its first-ever request for international firefighting reinforcements to the European Civil Protection Mechanism. Spain’s Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez said it was likely the largest such request ever facilitated by the EU.

“Climate change is fuelling more extreme wildfires, but adaptation isn’t keeping pace. We need to see a shift in thinking and a greater focus on prevention," Keeping adds.

This photo, provided by France's Securite Civile shows French fire fighters heading to a wildfire near Corporales, northern Spain on 20 August. Securite Civile via AP

The scale of the fires across the Iberian Peninsula has put incredible pressure on resources.

More than 380,000 hectares of land have burned in Spain since the start of 2025 - almost five times the yearly average. In Portugal, more than 260,000 hectares have been lost. That is close to 3 per cent of the country’s land mass and three times the average area burned by wildfires in a year.

The total area lost to wildfires across the two countries so far this year is roughly four times the size of Greater London. Together, fires in Spain and Portugal make up around two-thirds of Europe’s total burned area for 2025, which, in August, passed one million hectares for the first time since records began in 2006, according to the European Forest Fire Information System.

Spain is being ‘hit hard’ by climate change

At least eight people have been killed by the blazes, and tens of thousands have been forced to evacuate. Smoke led to dangerous air quality in Spain and Portugal and has travelled as far as France, the UK and Scandinavia.

Friederike Otto, a climate science Professor at the Centre for Environmental Policy, says Spain is being “hit hard” by climate change.

Related

Summer 2025 was UK's hottest on record and experts say 'extremes' like this are becoming more common

14-year-old boy confesses to deliberately starting several fires in Portugal, police say

“These enormous fires follow the devastating floods in Valencia and another summer of relentless heat above 40°C,” she says.

“Extreme weather is becoming more frequent, but deaths and damages are preventable. Every level of government must work together to adapt to climate change. For wildfires, there’s an urgent need to control vegetation in rural areas, particularly land that has been abandoned by farmers and shepherds.”

Public opinion in Spain has focused on the decline of rural activities, resulting in the growth of vegetation that has fuelled fires. Rural depopulation and an ageing population across parts of both Spain and Portugal have left forest land unmanaged. Fewer people and less traditional grazing have seen natural vegetation control sharply decline, leaving a lot of fuel for fires.

The wildfires in Europe show that 1.3°C of warming today is already incredibly dangerous. Without a faster shift away from fossil fuels, we could hit 3°C this century. Wildfires at this level would be catastrophic. Friederike Otto Climate science Professor at the Centre for Environmental Policy

But, Professor Otto adds, ultimately, the world needs to stop burning fossil fuels.

“The wildfires in Europe show that 1.3°C of warming today is already incredibly dangerous. Without a faster shift away from fossil fuels, we could hit 3°C this century. Wildfires at this level would be catastrophic.”

urn:contentItem:6GM8-88P3-RXCR-B154-00000-00Felipe VI encourages the resumption of trips cancelled due to the fires because those affected "require everyone's affection".2025-08-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:56:33ZLexisNexisFelipe VI encourages the resumption of trips cancelled due to the fires because those affected "require everyone's affection".


King Felipe VI has acknowledged that during the three-day visit to areas affected by the fires in Castilla y León, Galicia and Extremadura has felt the "satisfaction of being able to be close to all the people" who have suffered closely the fires, and has encouraged citizens to resume the canceled trips because those affected "require the affection of all".


Thus, he regretted that there have been "many towns, municipalities, small villages" that have not been able to "materially visit" as they have done this Friday in Rebollar, Cabezabellosa and Hervás, in the province of Cáceres, so they have concentrated "in some places in agreement with the authorities to organize it better and also make everyone's work easier".
The King and Queen have visited this Friday some of the localities affected by the great fire of Jarilla, which has devastated more than 17,400 hectares in three regions of the north of Cáceres: Valle del Jerte, Trasierra-Tierras de Granadilla and Valle del Ambroz. There they have shared with the neighbors their concerns and have thanked their work to the firefighting teams that have been fighting the fire for days.
In any case, he pointed out that what they have wanted with this series of visits has been "to convey to all a message of support, a message of affection, of affection, a message in which they perceive that they are cared for by the State" and by all the administrations that compose it.
After recognizing that it is a "complex" State, he stressed that it is also "very powerful", as has been seen "reflected in the reality on the ground", in relation to the variety, specialty and professionalism of many operatives, personnel from different backgrounds, not only from the General State Administration, Armed Forces, Security Forces and Corps of the UME, but also all the services that are "permanently on the ground".
And also accompanying not only those affected who have suffered in their lives, fortunately "there have not been many personal losses", referring to the four victims that "are certainly irreparable", but that "for the dimension of the tragedy, human life has been preserved in its great majority".
"WE MUST MOVE FORWARD".
However, he regretted that property, life projects and homes have been lost, which is what we must now "try to help to move forward" and to recover "as far as possible those lives".
On the other hand, he invited everyone to make "a reflective, serene, humble balance" on how to improve, in this case, in the tasks of fighting forest fires.
"The plans are useful until the reality overflows them and if that is so, it must be analyzed and put together at all administrative levels, all agencies involved and improve either the policy and regulatory framework, either direct action on the ground or how to improve in all the work of prevention that has also been reflected," argued the monarch.
Finally, he insisted that they want to leave a message of "proximity", of "being close to the citizens and being part of their concerns, of their tragedy in some cases and of the collective feeling that is so important for a people, for a community".
At this point, he referred to the importance of "transmitting the image that the valleys are there and require the visit of all and the affection of all", and in this sense he encouraged all those who had plans or canceled plans to come and visit all these beautiful lands" that have suffered the impact of the flames.
For her part, Doña Letizia told the media that in these three days of visiting the affected areas they have "felt the sadness, the desolation of the neighbors", but they have also told them how it has been their "gratitude to see together working" to State Security Forces and Corps, firefighters, civil protection, volunteers, so many people who have also helped.
"On the one hand that sadness, on the other hand that gratitude," he insisted, to abound in that "everywhere" have heard the "need for reflection, not only with the issues of prevention, but also with depopulation and the need to fix population in the rural environment." "We have heard very repeatedly the same advice".
These statements were made in the town of Hervás in Cáceres, when after taking a family photo with the mayors of the affected municipalities of Extremadura, they addressed a few words to journalists to show their impressions on this trip in which they have also received the affection of the people of Extremadura.
The visit of this Friday of the monarchs to Extremadura has begun in Rebollar, the smallest village in the Jerte Valley that had to be evacuated for three nights and where they have held a meeting with farmers, farmers and people attached to the land in which they have stressed the importance of addressing depopulation in rural areas as the settlement in the territory ensures better care of the environment.
Then they moved to Cabezabellosa, where they have been received by 500 people in the square between applause and cheers. There they greeted members of the firefighting teams of UME, Army, Civil Guard, Civil Protection, National Parks, Infoex Plan, Tragsa, BRIF Pinofranqueado Miteco, Red Cross Extremadura, Firefighters of the Provincial Fire Service of Cáceres, 112, Local Police, Natural Environment Agents, Psychologists, social workers, Forest Fire Extinguishing Service of Andalusia, among others.

urn:contentItem:6GKF-VD33-RY0C-902B-00000-00Matilda Lutz transformed into 'Red Sonja' with weights, swords and grit2025-08-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:56:33ZLexisNexisENTERTAINMENT: LATEST & ENTERTAINMENT: MOVIE NEWSMatilda Lutz transformed into 'Red Sonja' with weights, swords and gritBrian Truitt, USA TODAY

Starring as the title warrior of the fantasy action movie “Red Sonja,” Matilda Lutz emerges from a pool of fake blood, slathered in liquid that matches her crimson hair, a changed woman ready to slash her enemies.

It might not be everyone’s cup of tea, but Lutz lives for getting caked in grime and covered in whatever for her art. “For people, it's very hard to understand why I love it,” the 34-year-old Italian actress says, laughing. “I don't understand their point of view because I love being dirty.

“It's so much fun for me to leave reality. Life can be so boring sometimes, so it's fun to get to do things that are outside the box and crazy.”

It's a mindset that helped convince “Red Sonja” director MJ Bassett that Lutz was her perfect “She-Devil with a Sword” for the new movie (available to rent and buy Aug. 29 on demand). “That’s my kind of actor,” Bassett acknowledges. “When you find somebody who's your kindred spirit, you go, ‘Yep, that's it. Come play.’ ”

Join our Watch Party! Sign up to receive USA TODAY's movie and TV recommendations right in your inbox

Link to Image

“Red Sonja” centers on a heroine who’s been seeking the tribe of people she lost after a barbarian attack when she was a little girl. Now a protector of animals and a champion of the downtrodden, Sonja runs afoul of the tyrant Draygan (Robert Sheehan) and ends up enslaved alongside other gladiators for sport, ultimately leading a revolt alongside her new compatriots.

“I love that she tries to be invincible, but she's actually allowing herself to feel the pain and channel it,” Lutz says of her character.

Bassett says that Lutz brings “compassion and humanity” to Red Sonja, created by pulp writer Robert E. Howard in the 1930s and adapted into comic books by Roy Thomas in the ‘70s. “Yeah, she can chop your head off and stab you and fight dragons, monsters and things,” Bassett says. But at the same time, the movie is “about empathy and it's about trying to save a world faced with destruction.”

While Lutz was initially unfamiliar with how much of a pop-culture icon Red Sonja was, Bassett says she grew up a fan as “a child of the video boom in the '80s” who always loved sword-and-sorcery tales. Even those who aren't into comics or fantasy might recognize the visual of "that big busty barbarian woman in the chainmail bikini with flaming red hair, with a sword probably hacking the head off a snake."

Link to Image

As a trans filmmaker, Bassett wanted her Sonja to be a real, complex personality in a fantasy world rather than a woman “drawn by men for men” or, conversely, a feminist icon. “There's going to be people who push back and say Matilda's not physical enough (or) hasn't got big enough boobs or whatever it's going to be, and MJ didn't understand the character,” she says. “It's like, well, I've been chasing an opportunity to make my version of the character since I was a teenager.”

Bring up that "not physical enough" bit at your own peril. To play Sonja, Lutz put on 13 pounds of muscle through weight training and a diet where she consumed 2,600 calories a day, “which for me was a lot,” she says. “I was eating all day, basically. That was the hardest part.” And while she had a sports background, Lutz found herself diving into sword fighting, martial arts and horseback riding all for the first time.

“I love animals (but) it’s nerve-wracking to be around horses. They’re so powerful,” Lutz says. “I had all this training with the horses on the ground with no saddle, no bridle, where I had to lay down with the horse and feel his breathing and sleep with the horse." She also learned to connect with the animal through "little gestures, like touching him in front of the leg and he would kneel down.”

As for Sonja’s swordplay, Lutz started with a prop plastic sword and even that was “so heavy,” she says. “I have a small wrist and I couldn't do the things and I was like, ‘Oh, my God, will I be able to do this?’ And then little by little, I just realized that I was so determined in getting there. I was so eager to do everything I could.”

Bassett confirms that enthusiasm: She was wowed watching Lutz fighting dudes “relentlessly” in a forest fire sequence that felt like “standing inside an oven," all while clad in "skimpy" armor.

“There's nothing she wouldn't do,” the director says. “The actress and the character become one in the same at that point. Yeah, she has little wrists and she's not the biggest, bulkiest person in the world, but it doesn't make any difference when you are dedicated and committed in that way.”

This article originally appeared on USA TODAY: Matilda Lutz transformed into 'Red Sonja' with weights, swords and grit

urn:contentItem:6GMX-5103-RS0N-Y50M-00000-00Disaster declared as drought pushes South Korea's Gangneung to brink2025-09-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:56:33ZLexisNexisSTATE AND REGIONAL NEWSDisaster declared as drought pushes South Korea's Gangneung to brinkThe Korea Herald, Seoul / Asia News Network

Sep. 1—SEOUL(The Korea Herald/ANN) — South Korea is grappling with an escalating water crisis in Gangneung, Gangwon Province, where President Lee Jae Myung declared a "state of national disaster" over the weekend after drought pushed the region's main reservoir to unprecedented lows.

On Sunday, the Obong Reservoir, which supplies nearly 87 percent of the city's household water, fell below the 15 percent storage threshold widely regarded as the minimum for potable supply, making further distribution nearly impossible.

By 7:40 a.m. Sunday, storage had dropped to 14.9 percent, down 0.4 percentage point from the previous day. With levels slipping past the critical line, the city government began shutting off 75 percent of household meters and halted the supply of agricultural water.

Lee's disaster declaration Saturday marked the first time a natural disaster has prompted such a measure.

In previous years, such disaster zone declarations were limited to social disasters, such as the Yangyang wildfire in 2005, the Taean oil spill in 2007, the Goseong wildfire in 2019 and the Uljin-Samcheok forest fire from 2022.

The emergency measure is issued when a disaster occurs or is likely to occur, enabling the government to mobilize necessary personnel, equipment and supplies.

According to the Ministry of Interior and Safety, the order took effect as of 7 p.m., Saturday, after Lee visited the Obong Reservoir and presided over a drought response meeting at Gangneung City Hall.

The order also came a day after the Gangwon provincial government formally requested the central government declare it a disaster, citing deteriorating conditions.

Following the city's disaster declaration, the Gangwon provincial government held a drought response meeting Sunday and raised its emergency response posture to Level 2 under the Central Disaster and Safety Countermeasures Headquarters' system.

In Korea, a Level 2 response entails the full-scale mobilization of all administrative resources, with the provincial vice governor serving as the head of the headquarters.

According to the Gangwon Fire Headquarters, 71 fire department water tankers have been deployed as of 9 a.m., Sunday, including 50 water tankers mobilized by the National Fire Agency, with plans to supply an additional 2,500 metric tons of water every day.

The government has created a support group, bringing together officials from key ministries and local governments, including Gangneung city and Gangwon Province, to mobilize resources, mitigate the drought's impact and ease inconvenience for residents.

The drought in Gangneung has been coined a "flash drought" by experts, caused by scarce rainfall and record-breaking heat waves that quickly evaporated the little amounts of rain in the city.

According to weather records from the Korea Meteorological Administration, Gangneung's cumulative rainfall this year until Friday was 404.2 millimeters, just 40 percent of the city's average from previous years.

Less than 5 mm of rain is forecast to fall in Gangneung during the day on Monday, far below the level required to relieve the city of its longstanding drought. No further rainfall is forecast until Sept. 10 at the earliest.

Depending on rain forecasts within the next few weeks, the government expects the water storage levels in Obong Reservoir to drop to 9.7 percent within four weeks if no significant rain occurs.

Water scarcity in Gangneung is far from a new phenomenon.

Since the 1990s, Gangneung has repeatedly experienced periodic droughts and water supply disruptions, highlighting the vulnerability of its water management system.

In 2002 a typhoon cut tap water for four days, in 2009 an extreme drought left supplies depleted and in 2014 reservoir levels plunged again before a sudden downpour offered temporary relief. As recently as the summer of 2024, levels fell below 30 percent, prompting citywide conservation measures.

The frequent droughts in Gangneung are attributed to its geographical location, which makes it especially prone to water shortages.

Situated on the east coast and separated from the rest of the peninsula by the Taebaek Mountains, Gangneung receives less consistent rainfall than other parts of the country in the west. Much of its annual precipitation also comes in short, heavy bursts during typhoons, which often flow out toward the sea without replenishing reservoirs.

Gangneung's heavy dependence on the Obong Reservoir only adds to the problem; it lacks the storage capacity of larger multipurpose dams and dries out more quickly during prolonged heat waves, which have become a norm as the climate crisis worsens.

For decades, local authorities have floated plans such as releasing water from Doam Dam in neighboring Pyeongchang to supplement Gangneung's supply, but the proposal stalled amid strong opposition from civic and environmental groups over pollution and ecological damage.

Observers note that while groups opposed the plan, they failed to suggest viable alternatives, while the city government, central authorities and Korea Hydro & Nuclear Power Co., which operates the dam, all deflected responsibility.

Experts warn that unless Gangneung shifts from crisis-driven, short-term solutions to sustainable water management, the city is destined to repeat the same cycle of water scarcity.

"While emergency drought measures often focus on rationing or building new infrastructure, Gangneung should also turn to sustainable solutions such as rainwater harvesting," professor Han Moo-young from Seoul National University's Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering said during a radio interview with MBC.

Han pointed out that "The city receives about 1.5 billion tons of rainfall a year, but most of it is simply allowed to run off into the sea."

"If rain falling on the rooftops of large facilities, such as gyms or schools, were collected and reused, Gangneung could diversify its sources instead of relying only on mountain reservoirs," Han underscored.

urn:contentItem:6GMX-5SR3-RWHW-G066-00000-00A bracelet for Minister Grande (not hyphenated) Marlaska2025-09-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:56:33ZLexisNexisA bracelet for Minister Grande (not hyphenated) Marlaska


Just look at how particular the world is. Some gypsies shoot each other over a matter of horns and two of them die. It happened in Avila at the end of August. The news in all the media was: "A confrontation between two families". The offender cannot be "racialized", unless he is from Madrid. "A man from Madrid investigated for starting a forest fire while he was summering in Extremadura". He was arrested a few days ago. To make matters worse, it turns out that the "Madrileño" is not such. He is a resident of Mejorada del Campo. The news in ABC and El Mundo is signed by some writers from Extremadura. Surely they are careful not to confuse a "serón" with a "calabazón". It is a sambenito for the Madrileños to blame us for the evil of others, on this occasion caused by a Mejoreño.


Last Thursday our salty Minister of the Interior appeared in the Senate. In Cadiz, where he is a deputy, they are crazy about him. He spoke about fires. The PP had registered three requests for appearances and he was the first one. He was obliged to attend and complained at the very beginning of his deposition: "I cannot agree with the partisan use of the Senate... to serve the interests of a party and its strategy of harassment and demolition of the Government, based, on many occasions, on manipulation and noise". Having said that, he went on to detail a gibberish of bodies, competences and dates. Summary of a Government that shows its seams when it comes to go all together.
It is a hoax that the minister arrived at the Plaza de la Marina Española riding a Zero FX-ZF7.2, the electric motorcycle with which SEPRONA agents patrol along paths and steep places, always careful not to disturb the local fauna and to reduce the emissions footprint. The guards are not convinced by these motorcycles and their associations have asked for them to be immobilized. Senator Santamaria, from the PP, asked him about this issue. "Why don't you buy them SUVs, as you have always done, as seems logical? Why do they have to guard areas larger than 2,000 square kilometers with this type of motorcycles?" And Grande replied, with that tone between dismissive and arrogant, that they (the Government) at least buy them vehicles, unlike others. It was obvious that they had ruined the end of his vacation.
It is well known that the unions are a bunch of soreheads and on this occasion they could not be less so. The JUCILunions heated up the Minister's appearance by denouncing what they consider a reckless imprudence. That "SEPRONA's staff is overflowing, aged and insufficient to cover with dignity the extensive national geography and the growing complexity of environmental crimes". They ask him to answer "for the lack of foresight that is putting Spain and its ecosystems at risk". And what did the Minister answer when questioned in the Senate? Well, the same as with the motorcycles: apples I bring. He did, however, praise the professionalism and efficiency of the Civil Guard. An affirmation that, said by him, sounds more false than the Sevillian toughs.
"Reinforce the structure of the UME, with the creation of new battalions; urgently increase the SEPRONA staff, with adequate resources and long-term planning; professionalize Civil Protection". These are some of the 50 measures of the Partido Popular which Feijóo presented on August 25. The Minister of the Interior ignored them. "Spanish citizens do not need... insults or denialism; nor measures that are limited to placing telematic bracelets on arsonists, as if that were going to fix the problem of fires in our country." Marlaska has a tone of voice that does not accompany him when he wants to ridicule the adversary. "Measures that are limited to placing bracelets"... In the document presented by the Popular Party that is only one -the 38th- of 50.
The PP proposes the creation of "a National Register of Pyromaniacs to identify those convicted of arson". A legal instrument that exists in the very modern and democratic California since 2009. Also in the State of Illinois and in the State of Montana. "It's not going to solve all arson cases. It's not designed for that, says William Soqui, chief of the Cathedral City fire department, a stone's throw from Los Angeles. It's meant to give investigators another tool to help them narrow down the suspect pool and track down people convicted of a crime." A registry that is already contemplated in the Galician Forestry Law - in force since June 2012. I do not know if the Galician "register of offenders" has served any purpose. Although it is not the same if the Government of Sánchez does it: in this case I am certain that it will not be of any use. It would be a plurinational registry.
The bracelet, if it helps to combat the problem, fine. But it seems to be a coup de effect to give people something to talk about. If we are looking for a headline, it would make more sense to commit to increasing convictions. In August 2023, the Italian government increased the minimum sentence from four to six years.
A politician's job is a thankless one, and even more so if he is in the opposition. You present a document - a Comprehensive Plan - with your proposals, worked on by those in charge of the negotiation. With interesting initiatives. But, I don't know if it is at the suggestion of the guru on duty or on your own initiative, you go and say something about the registry and the bracelet. A political leader does not have to be witty or bullying, there are plenty of them in Spain. It is better to be serious and responsible. What is said to be normal. But that is a matter of taste.

urn:contentItem:6GM8-88F3-RX6H-2026-00000-00The King and Queen of Spain in Extremadura for the fires: "May everyone visit this beautiful land".2025-08-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:56:33ZLexisNexisThe King and Queen of Spain in Extremadura for the fires: "May everyone visit this beautiful land".


The Kings of Spain, Don Felipe VI and Doña Letizia, have embraced Extremadura this Friday to support those affected by the fires that have ravaged this land this summer. They have felt the warmth of the neighbors in the north of the region in a visit with three stops: Rebollar, Cabezabellosa and Hervás, where they have ended up making a call that this autonomous community is still green and known.


"The valleys in their great proportion are still there and we encourage everyone to visit this beautiful land," said Felipe VI from Hervás, the municipality in which part of its mountain, which is at the top of the mountains, has been burned by the Jarilla fire, the largest in the history of this autonomous community, which burned in ten days 17,300 hectares of the regions of Ambroz, Jerte and Trasierra.
"We have transmitted a message of support, affection and affection so that the neighbors perceive that they are cared for by the State and the whole of the administrations, which is complex but also very powerful. And that has been seen with the professionalism of the various troops," he added before inviting reflection. "Later, we must make a reflective, serene and humble balance on the part of everyone to see how to improve," he said.
"In these three days we have felt the sadness and desolation of the neighbors, but also the gratitude of seeing the State Security Forces and Corps working together. Everywhere we have heard the need for prevention and to fix the population in rural areas", added Doña Letizia at the end of a day that first took them to Rebollar.
In this municipality, the only one that had to be evacuated from the Jerte Valley by the fire in Jarilla, have arrived at 11.30 am. Many of their neighbors have been able to greet them with applause and shouts of 'long live the Kings'. After shaking their hands and approaching them, they have contemplated the Valley from Rebollar, a picture full of cherry trees. The part devastated by the fire is in the upper part and the black scorched part begins to be visible on the road that joins El Torno with Cabezabellosa.
There, in Rebollar, there have been emotional and curious moments. The Queen has approached a lady who was carrying a recently adopted puppy and whom she has named 'Fuego'. She has also taken in her arms a child who was not more than two years old and has greeted neighbors like Maruchi, a woman who had just turned 88 and was very proud that the Kings visited her village. "I had never seen them before and I am thrilled that they are coming to see the smallest municipality in the Jerte Valley".
The King and Queen were sympathetic to those affected, especially the businessmen, ranchers and farmers who have lost what feeds them. Among them was Eduardo Sánchez. "I have lost a farm with 80 chestnut trees," he said while Antonio Sanchez commented that he has a goat farm that has been saved. "Two thirds of the mountain range has been burned, but we have been privileged," he said while the King and Queen were about to greet them.
Thanks for fighting the flames
It was at the second stop, in Cabezabellosa, where Don Felipe and Doña Letizia had a massive reception. More than half a thousand neighbors have greeted them in a square where the King and Queen have shown their gratitude to the professionals who have been fighting the fire this summer. As a representation of them, members of the UME, Army, Civil Guard, Civil Protection, National Parks, INFOEX Plan, Tragsa, BRIF of Pinofranqueado, Red Cross Extremadura, Firefighters of the Provincial Fire Fighting Service of Cáceres, 112, local police, environmental agents, psychologists, social workers and Forest Fire Fighting Service of Andalusia, among others, have chatted and have been photographed with Their Majesties.
"It is a satisfaction that they recognize our work after ten days fighting the fire in Jarilla," said Alvaro Hernandez minutes before greeting the Kings.
"We have felt the sadness and desolation, but also the gratitude of seeing together working State Security Forces and Corps", said the Queen.
"They have told us that they are very sorry," said Meli and Maria Luz, two neighbors of Cabezabellosa who have been able to speak with Don Felipe and Doña Letizia, who have spent almost an hour greeting the inhabitants of this town. There they have been applauded, cheered and given gifts. From t-shirts and roses to strips with the flag of Extremadura and bracelets. All before leaving their signature in the book of honor of the Town Hall and begin their journey to Hervás.
In this town, after two o'clock in the afternoon, they have been received between popular songs like 'El Redoble' by a thousand neighbors. After being photographed with them, they greeted the mayors of Hervás, Casas del Monte, Segura de Toro, Gargantilla, La Garganta, Cabezabellosa, Villar de Plasencia, Jarilla, Rebollar, Cabezuela del Valle, Navaconcejo, El Torno, Jerte and Tornavacas, all of them municipalities affected by the Jarilla fire, which covered a perimeter of 170 kilometers.
They then had lunch at the Hospedería de Hervás with them after a visit that was also attended by the president of the Junta de Extremadura, María Guardiola; the Minister of the Interior, Fernando Grande-Marlaska; the president of the Assembly, Blanca Martín; the Government Delegate in Extremadura, José Luis Quintana; the Minister of Presidency, Interior and Social Dialogue, Abel Bautista; the Minister of Forestry Management and Rural World, Francisco José Ramírez, and the President of the Provincial Council of Cáceres, Miguel Ángel Morales.

urn:contentItem:6GBB-B4M3-RVS6-B4V6-00000-00DURBIN INTRODUCED BILL TO CREATE CLIMATE BOND PROGRAMS TO FUND CLIMATE RESILIENCY PROJECTS2025-07-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:56:33ZLexisNexisDURBIN INTRODUCED BILL TO CREATE CLIMATE BOND PROGRAMS TO FUND CLIMATE RESILIENCY PROJECTSStates News ServiceWASHINGTON

The following information was released by Illinois Senator Richard J. Durbin:

The Climate Change Resiliency Fund for America Act would create a program similar to the national war bond program during World War II to support climate resiliency efforts

WASHINGTON U.S. Senate Democratic Whip Dick Durbin (D-IL) today reintroduced the Climate Change Resiliency Fund for America Act, which would authorize the U.S. Department of Treasury to issue from $200 million to $1 billion in state and local tax-exempt "climate bonds" annually for any American to purchase and contribute to the effort to address the impacts of climate change. Inspired by the national war bond program during World War II, these bonds would fund a new "Climate Change Resiliency Fund," to be administered by the Department of Commerce, for grants to finance climate resilient infrastructure projects to shore up the nation against extreme weather events like flash flooding, tornados, wildfires, and heat waves as these disasters increase in number and intensity across the country.

"We're seeing the impacts of climate change in real time as severe floods, uncontrollable wildfires, and extreme temperatures sweep across the country. We must address this existential threat through a coordinated national strategy, and soon," said Durbin. "Today, I'm reintroducing the Climate Change Resiliency Fund for America Act to offer the sale of 'climate bonds' to fund climate resiliency projects in front-line and environmental justice communities that experience disproportionate impacts from the crisis."

In addition to issuing "climate bonds," the Climate Change Resiliency Fund for America Act would create a bipartisan Climate Change Advisory Commission of 11 members appointed by the House of Representatives, the Senate, and the President to establish program requirements and vet and approve the projects financed by the Climate Change Resiliency Fund.

Climate resiliency projects would be determined by the Commission, and could include projects such as flood control, structural fortification, forest fire prevention, climate-smart agricultural practices, and cooling centers, among others. They also could include improvements to the supply chain and water security.

Eligible grant recipients include federal agencies and state and local governments, including utilities, tribes, transit groups, nonprofits, coalitions, public authorities, or other organizations as determined by the Secretary of Commerce. Most projects would require a 25 percent nonfederal match, but the Secretary would have authority to waive match requirements in disadvantaged communities. A portion of the fund would be set aside specifically for projects that will not require a match.

urn:contentItem:6GB6-2203-RRHP-145P-00000-00Vice President Inspects Solar Power Project in Oudomxay Province2025-07-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:56:33ZLexisNexisVice President Inspects Solar Power Project in Oudomxay Province

22 Jul 2025 (Lao News Agency) Vice President Bounthong Chitmany, member of the Politburo and permanent member of the Secretariat of the Party Central Committee, led a delegation on an inspection visit to the solar power project in Xay and Namo districts, Oudomxay Province last weekend.

(KPL) Vice President Bounthong Chitmany, member of the Politburo and permanent member of the Secretariat of the Party Central Committee, led a delegation on an inspection visit to the solar power project in Xay and Namo districts, Oudomxay Province last weekend.

Accompanying him were Mr. Bounkhong Lachiemphone, Secretary of the Oudomxay Provincial Party Committee and alternate member of the Party Central Committee; Mr. Zhang Sheping, Consul General of China in Luang Prabang; and other senior officials. The delegation was warmly welcomed by representatives from CGN Energy Technology Lao Co., Ltd., the developer of the project, who presented a progress report.

The Clean Energy Connection Project spans seven villages-Kiew Chalu, Chom Ong, Kiew Jaep, Nathua, Nambotakai, Houay Soi, and Mak Chuk-across Xay and Namo districts. The development covers a total area of over 2,090 hectares, of which 1,009 hectares are actively used. Compensation has been provided to 349 families for land use, covering 956 plots (2,022 hectares in total).

Phase 1 of the Northern Region Clean Energy Project aims to install 1,000 megawatts (MW) of solar capacity, with an estimated annual generation of 1,700 gigawatt-hours (GWh) of electricity. The concession agreement for the project was signed on September 12, 2024.

As of now, 45% of the construction has been completed. Key infrastructure developments include:

Full completion of the station site excavation (3.32 hectares), 45 pylon foundations, transformer bases, environmental green zones, and solar zone groundwork.

51.96% completion of erosion-control rock mesh, 39.21% completion of the production building, 34.63% completion of boundary walls.

12.12% completion of solar panel support structures, 6.57% installation of solar panels (equal to 85.41 MW installed).

84.7% completion of road infrastructure (90.643 km in total), 43.1% completion of transmission tower base excavation (25 pylons), 41.38% completion of concreting works for 24 pylons, 45 transmission towers installed, representing 7.76% of total planned.

The project also includes construction of a forest fire prevention observation post for monitoring environmental conditions and enhancing site safety. A concrete road has been built to improve access and logistics for transporting materials and equipment.

The solar power plant is expected to begin selling electricity commercially by the end of 2025.
